I found at least 3 differnt types of stack overflow in the indexer
CDT 3.1.0.200606120500

Doug, if you have trouble reproducing my indexer problems maybe you could send me the (updated) jar files with your fixes. Otherwise I can only test whatever is released on the calisto site (I don't have the time to build CDT to test the indexer)

Other than the exception appearing in the log, what else goes wrong? Just wondering why you marked this critical?

I can't fix these, certainly not for 3.1. We're just going to have to live with them for now.

Well nothing that needs the indexer works ("goto definition/declaration", "search C++", "search for references") and my guess is that the reason is simply that these errors lead to an unusable PDOM.

>I can't fix these, certainly not for 3.1.

That's a pity, as the release of CDT will be most likely rated (mostly) by the quality of it's indexer. If the indexer has serious bugs nobody will use it (we used the null indexer with 3.0, as all other indexers did not work reliably / made CDT reaaaly slow). If the indexer does not work CDT is nothing more but an editor.

These should not lead to an unusable PDOM. We do recover from the errors and I could remove the reporting but I want to know when these happen.

Which actually brings up that these errors are actually pretty rare. So I am not too concerned about them reflecting on the quality of the CDT, except for yourself, of course :).

Is this ACE/TAO still?

It is our project that uses ACE/TAO, so I know a lot of ACE/TAO get's indexed, as I can see lot of ACE stuff in the "C++ Index" view. Count symbols says 2394 files, 15098 macros, 21398 symbols, 84716 references, 21114 declarations, 20167 definitions (I wished I could select and copy that message instead of typing it).

The errors of the indexer unfortunately give no clue to what file(s) cause the problem.

The index view is also hard to navigate, as it does not support to do the "type search" that most Eclipse views support. I can see my classes in the index view (I don't know if I see all though) and I can use the context menu in the index view to "open definition". However if I try the same by selecting the class name in an editor (in a different file) and select "open definition" nothing happens.

Therfore I concluded that the index must be somehow "corrupt". Maybe that's not the case, but nevertheless neither the navigation from inside an editor nor the C++ search works with the index that get's created.

Note that (as far as I'm concerned) the index _is_ corrupt when it comes to templates.  No template classes are being added to the index, but template class non-template members are added.  These members are added to the wrong parent (ie instead of being under their correct parent they are under the enclosing namespace, or the root itself).  There's varying opinions how big a problem this is.

See bug 145066.  It would be interesting to see if these overflows go away when using the patch from 145066 (though I'm not sure we're that lucky :)).  Maybe Lothar can check out cdt.core from cvs, apply the patch and export a new jar to try with.

as said before I would be more than happy to help by testing potential fixes if somebody creates the jar files and I can download them (e.g. as attachments on this bug). But I have no time to set up an environment to build CDT on my own.

We have nightly builds of the CDT so there's no reason to attach jars.

But unless we can reproduce the problem, we can't fix it. That will be the real challenge. I don't see these exceptions with the environments I'm testing with. And some of them are pretty complex.

Even with bad information in the index, there's no reason why we should be getting stack overflows. There are better ways of handling bad data.

I attached a (compressed) jar to 145066 since the patch there has not been applied an hence is not in the nightly builds.

I agree that we need a reproducible test case.  These stack overflows worry me. Its one thing to say that the binding resolution should be more resistant to bad input but fixes like the one applied for bug 145245 are just bandaids that hide the real problem.

There are infinitely many ways the input can be wrong, we will never be able to handle them all, so its better to try and ensure the input is as correct as possible.

I volunteer to test anything I can download and install be it attachments or nightly builds. I am currently downloading the latest nightly to see if the attached jar from the other bug works with that.

If you can not reproduce the errors the best I can do is test whatever you have (as long as I have time for it). I would be happy if my testing contribution could make the CDT calisto release more stable than it is now.

P.S.
Doug, is the fact that c++ search and references/declarations don't work for me related to these stack overflows or is that a different problem?

Created an attachment (id=44467)
the full error log from the latest nightly build

I tried to use the attached jar from the other bug with the nightly build, but that failed, too. I tried many things like renaming the jar editing the manifest of the feature, to no avail. I guess if you want me to test some intermediate between the nightly builds you need to provide me with a complete download somewhere. A single jar seems not to work.

Thanks Enrico, this does it for me.  When I get a chance I'll step through and debug this.
In the case of the PDOM index, having a template type is equivalent to having an undefined type since the template types aren't in the index.  

I see this to be sort of good news in that its not the mishapen index that is the problem, but simply missing symbols.  Missing symbols are something that should be handled in general by the resolver.  Either the hookup to the PDOM has change this handling in some way, or we've simply found a bug that has always been hidden there.

Created an attachment (id=44957)
error log for nightly build 2006-06-20

another error log to keep you posted about how the latest nightly builds perform

Created an attachment (id=45123)
error log for nightly build 2006-06-22

Created an attachment (id=45169)
Preliminary patch

It seems like problem occurs because class name 
is searched in the scope of in-class variables... 
and found !

Proposed patch catches only this situation. 
It does not change whole searching workflow 
but forbids acception var instead of type.

It's not a common solution. I hate it for this.
But it seems to be working... 

What about another similar situations ?
Thanks, Oleg. I'll take a look at the patch as soon as the 3.1 maintenance branch is opened. I have found that any quick fix I've tried has broken the JUnits. It's a nasty house of cards.

Created an attachment (id=45185)
Patch to fix overflow

I thought I attached this patch last night, I don't know why it didn't stick.

This patch fixes the stack overflow that I get from Enrico's example.  It is a more general fix than just that specific example.

(In reply to comment #17)
> It seems like problem occurs because class name 
> is searched in the scope of in-class variables... 
> and found !

I did not look closely at Oleg's patch, but the class name is found in the class scope by design.  The C++ Spec specifically states this in section 9-2 "The class-name is also inserted into the scope of the class itself".

I don't remember the specific cases this affects, but I'm sure that looking at some of the 9 test failures this patch introduces would tell you.
Andrew, do you feel confident about putting this into 3.1? Today's the last day, well Sunday is but anyway...

(https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/attachment.cgi?id=45185)

Yes, the more I think about it the more I like this patch.  It closes a hole that caused us to resolve bindings that should not have been considered (leading to recursive loops).  It also brings the two cases (a set vs 1 name) closer together; there may be opportunity to collapse these 2 cases into 1 but that is a larger change better done next release.

The caveat is that I'm not currently set up to test this very much.  I've only run it against the case Enrico provided (and my simplified version) along with the existing junits.
If someone provides me with a downloadable full build (like the nightly ones), so that I can install it I volunteer to run it against my sources to see if it fixes the errors.
I'm finding the JUnits pretty complete in this area. If you get no further failures, I'd say go for it. I'll do some additional testing on Monday on the final build and maybe later today.
patch released
do you mean applied? If so, please tell the cdt-dev list.

(From update of attachment 45169)
+1 for the next patch

Created an attachment (id=45309)
error log for build I200606261600

latest error log
I'll be running through ACE+TAO. Hopefully I can see the errors.
*** Bug 144139 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 144543 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

I have resolved the stack over flow exceptions (I hope). As Andrew Niefer mentioned some time ago, the templates were getting added to the index as classes. This caused the major havoc you see with the stack overflows. I have fixed the PDOM so that templates are ignored, i.e. not added at all. The stack overflows have gone away and it appears there has been only a light degradation in the number of things captured by the index.

I will continue to work towards adding templates to the index but I can not promise this for CDT 3.1.1.
